STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 19, 2024
Crystal Michelle Wilson
Ennis Center for Children-Detroit
20100 Greenfield Rd,
DETROIT, MI, 48235-1803
RE: License#: CB820201107
Dear Ms. Wilson:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 4/17/2024 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rori Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
Enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201107
Licensee Group Organization: Ennis Center for Children Inc
Licensee Designee: Robert E Ennis
Chief Administrator: Crystal Michelle Wilson
Name of Agency: ENNIS CENTER FOR CHILDREN -
DETROIT
Agency Address: 20100 GREENFIELD RD
DETROIT, MI 48235-1803
Agency Telephone #: 3133422699
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all areas of foster care as provided in
R400.12203 to R400.12214 .
The agency requires an annual ICHAT and central registry clearance for all
employees as a way to maintain compliance with staff qualification rules
• Four of eight employee records reviewed where the employee was
employed over one year showed the respective employee's annual ICHAT
was completed late.
• Three of eight employee records reviewed where the employee was
employed over one year showed the respective employee's annual central
registery clearance was completed late.
Repeat Violation Established:
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 5/12/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or

her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of one new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of the
employee's 6-month evaluation due by 1/17/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 5/12/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child was due for a
medical exam on 8/2/2023 and a medical exam was not obtained until 11/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical
authority, which indicates that immunizations are
current or contraindicated, is sufficient documentation
of immunizations.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s
DTA/DTap/DT/td/Tda expired on 6/21/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.

One of eight open foster child records reviewed, where siblings were split, did not
show documentation of a June or July 2023 sibling visitation.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Prior to completing the child adoption assessment, the
adoption worker must make a minimum of two face-to-
face contacts with the child, with at least one in the
home, and one face-to-face with the child's current
caregiver, even if the caregiver(s) are not interested in
adopting the child. The contacts must be documented in
the child assessment.
In one of five open child adoption records reviewed the child’s adoption assessment
did not show two face-to-face contacts within the child assessment, as required by
the policy.
Repeat Violation Established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/12/2023.
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 5/12/2022.
ADM 330 Adoption Quarterly Progress Report
Quarterly progress reports, using the DHHS-614 are to
be completed each quarter.
In one of five open child adoption records reviewed the record showed the child’s
9/1/23-11/30/23 quarterly was completed 4 days late on 12/4/23.
Repeat Violation Established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/12/2023.
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 5/12/2022.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated

court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 2/16/2023-5/16/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
caregiver until 7/14/2023. This child’s 8/9/2023-11/6/2023 treatment plan
was not signed by the youth and caregiver until 1/9/2024.
• A second child’s 3/30/2023-6/27/2023 treatment plan was not signed by
the caregiver.
Repeat Violation Established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/12/2023.
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 5/12/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
ADM 330 Quarterly Progress Reports.
• The agency was apprised that each required face-to face contact with the child
and family must be shown in the quarterly report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12326 (1) Borrowed home.
• The agency was advised that listing the child’s date of placement onto the
borrowed bed agreement/agency form, showing that the certifying agency and
foster parent accepts the placement, may aid the agency in showing all
agreements/acceptances occurred prior to the child’s placement.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with that individual CAP is as follows.
The CAP related to the agency’s Interim inspection completed on 5/12/2023,
where the CAP was approved on 7/12/2023. The agency received 7 violations, 2
of which were repeat violations this year. The agency’s compliance around these
2 rule violations improved; the number of individual cases decreased from 3 to
2(out of the 8 cases reviewed both this year and in 2023) related to the one, and
remained the same as 1 individual case incident related to the other.
In the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection, 22 violations were established, 3 of which
were repeat violations this year. With the exception of the repeat violation related
to the agency’s required annual clearances pertaining to the staff qualification
standard that saw an increase in individual incidents, the individual incidents of
non-compliance related to the other 2 repeats was the same in one and a
decreased in the other. The agency will need to work with its human resource
department around corrective measures to obtain its required annual ICHATs and
central registry clearances timelier.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment date 4/1/2024 was reviewed. The
assessment reported the agency is either in full compliance or partial compliance
related to violations cited last year; and with respect to key performance indicators
(KPI) and their monthly management report (MMR). The Chief Administrator
reported staff turnover, workers and supervisors not consistently utilizing
departmental checklists to cross reference for policy compliance were factors that
impacted compliance. Additionally, that their office’s need to assist another
satellite office with tasks, created some minor difficulties; and adjustments were
required to try to ensure ongoing compliance.
The CA reported the corrective action plan brought attention for them related to
the areas needing oversight, served as a check and balance for staff, and the
need for supervisory guidelines and enforcement of supervisory accountability.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget for the year end 9/30/2024 for its foster
care and adoption programs respectively, as well as a 9/30/2023 agency
independent financial audit. No major concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the CA during the entrance conference; and with the
licensing supervisor and adoption supervisor during the onsite inspection; one
foster care worker, one licensing worker, and one adoption worker was

interviewed onsite. Workers reported feeling appreciated and supported, and
viewed the agency and supervisory staff as available and hands on. All staff
reported the agency is a good place to work. Areas of growth or improvements
indicated was for more staff so as to reduce current staff responsibilities, more
uniformity related to all satellite offices, and continued improved communication.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility revealed no safety issues or noted areas of concern.
The agency had all case records secured and has adequate office space and
equipment.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: The home did not have an operable smoke detector on each level
of occupancy.
Resolution: The agency reported observing and testing a properly installed smoke
detector in the home on 3/22/2024. The smoke detector was found to be in proper
working order. A photo of the install detector was provided. A special evaluation had
been opened on the foster home due to the reported issue.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
April 18, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 19, 2024
